narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: This class is incredibly illuminating for forestry studies and all MFs without sufficient fieldwork/practical experience should be required to take it. Foci on professionalism and practicality are invaluable. I dropped Managing Resources for this class, and it was well worth it. this is the closest thing to hands on real life learning that FES has to offer.
Excellent course--the most practical course I expect to take at FES.
This was the most practical course I took at FES. I think it should be developed into a full course--3cr, with an optional 4th credit for taking the southern field trip.

Written reports may overwhelm students, especially at the end of the semester.There's a need for a clearer schedule. Things moved aroud quite a bit and this could've caused confusion.The TA sometimes was slow to respond to students' questions / inquiries about the class. A couple of times I did not receive a response.THis is a 2-credit class&sometimes it felt like a 3-credit class.
7, 9 Field trips were great fun and educational, well organized. Jason was the most professional TA I have ever had. Mike and Jason were very helpful.
Hands-on applicability of the material and instructor. Nothing else at Yale is this useful for foresters.
It imparts real life experience about forestry operations.
the field trips
Field trips and Operations reports
Learning about machinery, roads, and the Southern field trip.
Mike has years of expertise in the field and really enjoys interacting and teaching students. This adds a lot to the energy of the class and the amount students learn.
Field trips - great for starting discussion on important topics.Provides on-the-ground experienceAllow students to get to know professionals.
The field trips and assignments. All good preparation for a real job.

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: not sure...
organization/syllabus/readings for each week

Make the class more organized. I felt like I didn't really ever know what was going on until a couple of days before each Friday's class. Make expectations clearer with students, and provide more opportunities to be in the field, this was the best and most helpful aspect of the class.

I would have appreciated more forays into some quantitative aspects of forest operations. The instructor made great effort on field trips (especially the southern U.S. field trip) to introduce us to figures on such things as prices, how much a truck can haul, what an average worker operating a harvester can cut, etc, but it would have been useful to have some section of lecture dedicated to such figures. Perhaps some exercises of some kind, creating operational budgets for some of the harvests we saw.
Clarity and organization in the logistics of the course.
I would have liked to have more reading assignments that explained the art of harvesting and road building.

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: Great
Incredibly helpful, always willing to help students find jobs
Mike and Jay were a dynamite team, a force of nature, an incredible juggernaut of academic power.
both were great
Very available and helpful, especially to scheduling needs.
Excellent.

Mike was helpful and although not on campus much, he was always willing to e-mail or talk on the phone. Jason was an excellent TA and the class would not have been nearly as informative and well-organized had he not been there to help Mike.
TA sometimes absentInstructor was always available
Top notch quality and availability from instructor and TA. I contacted both.

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: Great
This course is a must for MF students
This knowledge is essential to everything I want to do, and many more people should take this course.
I am a forestry student, and this is the only practical course offered at the school.
as an MF without practical experience, this was a must
Crucial.

This is a insider's look at how forest operations take place, the realities, constraints, and challenges or forest management. This kind of knowledge is key to rounding out what is otherwise a very theoretical and classroom based master of forestry curriculum at FES.
Every forester interested in conducting forest management should take this course.
This is one of the most necessary courses. The MF is a practical training program. This course succeeds in preparing us for a forestry career.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: wanted to know more about the real world of forestry
Reputation of the professor
it is extremely practical for a career as a forester
interest and suggestions from the TA
To learn about being an actual forester.

To gain a better understanding for on-the-ground forest management and operations. This is key tomy career in land and forest management and a subject that is not taught directly in many other forestry classes at FES.
It is an absolute necessity for anyone wanting to be in any way connected to the operational side of forestry.
Required. I wanted to learn this material and go on the field trips.

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: yes
Absolutely.
Yes; it was terrific
definitely, I think it exceeded my expectations.
Exceeded expectations
Absolutely.
I only wish there were more opportunities to be in the field since these field visits were the most helpful dimension of the class.
Yes.

Somewhat. Intensity dropped at mid-semester and then picked up quite quickly at the end of the semester.Some of the forestry operationswere only mentioned and never explained in full detail: chainsaw use, skidders.
Yes, and more.

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: yes
YEs
more than I thought I would get out of it
Exceeded expectations
Yes.
Isn't that the same as asking if it met my expectations? Yes, it did!
Yes. In some ways it went beyond my expectations, but I still feel my knowledge of the material is cursory. Real understanding comes with field experience.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: It was a good exercise
Sharing of knowledge and a look at working with teams in field forestry, as it may be in my future career.
For a field trip, I worked with a partner. He grasped some of the concepts better than I, so he explained them to me. We worked effeciently and got the assignment done in good time.

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: It is hard to schedule activities, you have to make it a priority.

Write your field trip reports as soon after the field trip as possible. You will forget more than you think possible, even just a few days or weeks later, and the quality will suffer, as will the learning points.
Absolutely take it - phenomenal.

Do the readings and take an active approach to learning in the class so that, despite the relaxed teaching environment that Mike sets up, you still get alot out of the class. Also, ask lots of questions and make an effort to participate in as many field exercises as possible.
Think "temperate". There's a very small tropical/subtropical component. Course largely restricted to the Northeast.
Do the reading before hand and write down questions to ask during lecture.
